description.narrative: Preventing Violent Extremism through Promoting Tolerance and Respect for Diversity

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Office on Drug and Crime

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

provider-org.narrative: United Nations Office on Drug and Crime

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Result indicator (Based on Agreement with EU : Aug2018-Feb2020) 1.1. Number of networks of practitioners established, including online forum 1.2. Number of research papers produced 1.3. Number of national and regional dialogues held 2.1. Number of countries with methodology for holistic NAPs developed 2.2. Number of countries included gender and civil society commitments in NAPs methodologies 2.3. Facilitate the process of implementing NAPs on PVE 3.1. Creation of number ExtremeLives online regional network 3.2. Number of Facebook Live videos produced on understanding VE 3.3. Number of participants trained through 6 workshops to produce positive counter narratives to violent extremism 3.4. Support local CSOs in all four target countries to address the challenges around the gendered extremist narrative. This includes trainings in all target countries and the development of a training manual for the production of video content for civil society actors. 3.5 Number of Youth entrepreneurship programmes started in all two countries creating economic opportunities to prevent recruitment into violent extremist groups
Result indicator for Project in Maldives and Sri Lanka (Based on Agreement with EU : Dec 2019-June 2021) 1.1 Working group set up and modalities agreed upon 1.2 # of sub grants issued to support working group activities 1.3 # of South to South exchange(s) held on establishment of early warning monitoring systems 1.4 Establishment of Platform that collects, consolidates, and presents evidence-based data on hate speech, social tension/cohesion and violence 1.5 # of bi-annual reports produced on social tensions and violence tension/cohesion and violence 1.6 # of annual reports produced on social tensions and violence
2.1 # # of national dialogues held between government, civil society (particularly with women, youth and religious groups), and PVE experts 2.2 # of key stakeholder meetings held with the Counter Radicalisation Committee to implement an i

comment.narrative:
Based on Agreement with EU (Aug2018-Feb2020) 0 : Lack of inclusive national policies and programmes on Preventing Violent Extremism 0 : Lack of in-depth research into the complex drivers of violent extremism in Asia 0 : Lack of inclusion of young people in creating positive messages and little awareness of key VE issues online

PVE Project in Sri Lanka 1.1 – 1: CSO working group established comprising 8 CSOs. One working group knowledge sharing sessions conducted. Second steering committee meeting held on PCVE interventions in collaboration with UNODC and RCO. A Technical level working group planned for 2021 after assessing the political climate. 1.2 -8: Grants recipients finalized and are expected to from CSO experts’ group on responding to violent extremism and promoting of social cohesion. 8 sub- grants issued for the working group to implement individual project activities. 1.3 -0: Initial discussions held with UNDP Crisis Bureau and the Knowledge management team of UNDP, New York to organize a knowledge exchange between the UNDP team in South Sudan and the Project teams in Sri Lanka and the Maldives. 1.4 -1: A crisis risk dashboard (CRD) to generate early warning established. Datasets secured for continuity. Further development of the virtual platform undergoing. 1.5 -0 1.6 – 1: A primary data research on identifying the drivers of violent extremism and the spread of hate speech in Sri Lanka conducted. The draft report submitted. 2.1 –0: TOR developed and the assignment advertised with the anticipation of working with a university partner in order to enhance credibility of the analysis. 2.2 –0: Delayed due to the current political climate in the country which is being assessed by the UN at the moment. The pandemic outbreak is expected to further affect the implementation of the dialogues. 2.3 –0: This has been delayed due to the transitional phase of the government and the current changes to the government priorities due to the pandemic situation. It is also important to note that investigations into the Easter attacks is ongoing and that it’s important to understand the government’s position on a PCVE strategy following the investigations 2.4 –0: An agreement has been signed with the Kothalawala Defence University to launch a comprehensive program on nonviolent communication and responsible journalism for state and non-state media actors, aspiring young students. 2.5 –0: UNDP BRH developed a concept note for the knowledge exchange in close consultation with UNDP Sri Lanka and Maldives and methodology for the exchange is being developed with support from an expert consultant. 2.6 -1: A comprehensive program conducted covering 12 villages with the participation of 226 women and 50 men. 3.1 –1: Agreement signed with a think tank to conduct the analysis. Methodological framework developed. First set of reports expected in December, 2020. 3.2 –1: Agreement signed with a think tank to conduct the analysis. Methodological framework developed. First set of reports expected in December, 2020. 3.3 –2: Two Webinars were completed on laying the groundwork for conversations on PVE with the participation of 298 female (238) and male (60) participants. 3.4 –0: 60 online and 20 face-to face dialogues successfully conducted and completed a story book based on life experiences of people during the pandemic prepared. These programs involved the participation of 57 religious leaders who engaged in dialogue with young women and men as well as civil society leaders. 3.5 –1: 100 youth start-ups selected (60 males, and 40 females) and training provided on development finance, and coping strategies. 3.6 –0: Human Pictures completed a comprehensive strategy and methodology to develop the video documentaries. The BRH team hired a Behaviour Science specialist to provide a comprehensive strategy and methodology to measure the impact. The Project also hired an animator and graphic designer to support with publicizing the new visual identity of ExtremeLives. 3.7 -0: The BRH team hired LoveFrankie, a social change organizaton. They are currently in the process of developing the programme strategy which will be submitted to UNDP for final review on 15 December 2020. UNDP BRH also established a partnership with Facebook’s South Asia Office to support this activity.
PVE Project in Maldives 1.1 – 1: UNDP Maldives working with Maldives National University on the methodology for hate signs and social tensions monitoring,with national working group in development. 1.2 -0: To be disbursed as per guidance from WG, next quarter 1.3 -0: Initial discussions held with UNDP Crisis Bureau and the Knowledge management team of UNDP, New York to organize a knowledge exchange between the UNDP team in South Sudan and the Project teams in Sri Lanka and the Maldives. 1.4 -0: international firm hired to develop Data Platform 1.5 -0: Work begun on compiling annual report 1.6 - 0: Work begun on compiling annual report 2.1 –1: Consultant hired and work initiated with Education Ministry who will be working on supporting the main national dialogue 2.2 –1: Procurement processinitiated for International Firm, and currently in desk review stage with Youth Ministry. This consultant will support in convening key stakeholder meetings for NAP implementation. 2.3 –0: Consultant hired and currently developing the Internet Literacy Programme 2.4 –01: One consultation held with educators and civil society representatives on detecting early signs. 2.5 –0: UNDP BRH developed a concept note for the knowledge exchange in close consultation with UNDP Sri Lanka and Maldives and methodology for the exchange is being developed with support from an expert consultant. 3.1 –1: Journal article detailing the methodology of the survey, has been submitted to the Maldives National Journal of Research (MNJR) for publication. A Statistical Release (I) also have been drafted for internal purposes with selected questions. 3.2 –2: Virtual Dialogue conducted with 70 participants from relevant government agencies and CSOs. Badhahi social media messaging campaign rolled-out 3.3 –2: Two Youth Camp with 50 participants conducted 3.4 –0: Human Pictures completed a comprehensive strategy and methodology to develop the video documentaries. The BRH team hired a Behaviour Science specialist to provide a comprehensive strategy and methodology to measure the impact. The Project also hired an animator and graphic designer to support with publicizing the new visual identity of ExtremeLives. 3.5 –0: 3.6 –0: 3.7 -0: The BRH team hired LoveFrankie, a social change organization. They are currently in the process of developing the programme strategy which will be submitted to UNDP for final review on 15 December 2020. UNDP BRH also established a partnership with Facebook’s South Asia Office to support this activity. 4.1 -0: Procurement underway on hiring international expert. 4.2-0
PVE Project in Southeast Asia Phase II OP1.1 : 0 (NAPS), 0 (SNAPS) NAPS Indonesia: UNDP is in the recruitment process of engaging two Consultants to conduct the activities related to policy engagement under Output 1, including to facilitate policy engagements and the development of operational regulations. UNDP finalized a TOR for support on strengthening government responses to hate speech and misinformation surrounding COVId-19. 22 October, the project conducted a workshop on “The Empowerment of the Mass Organization in Addressing The COVID-19 Crisis” which included 38 participants (16 female and 22 male) to facilitate interaction between policymakers and mass organizations to discuss the role and potential contribution of mass organization in addressing the COVID-19 crisis. Malaysia: Submitted Project Document to the Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA) on 6 October 2020 to begin process of providing support in developing a National Action Plan on the Prevention of Violent Extremism (NAP PVE) and wait for cabinet approval. Philippines: UNDP supported the enrollment of NAP related partners in an online Professional Certificate Course on Countering Terrorism and Violent Extremism with the International Center for Parliamentary Studies (OCPS) 19-23 October 2020 Thailand: In July 2020, UNDP convened meeting with National Security Council and UNODC where parties agreed on ’One UN approach’ for engagement and support to Thai government on P/CVE agenda.
SNAPS Indonesia: The consultants hired to support the implementation of NAP on P/CVE will also support the development of Sub-National Action Plan (SNAPs). Philippines: Technical meetings were conducted between the Ministry of the Interior and local Government (MILG) of the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM) and UNDP technical personnel in developing the Bangsamoro CORE framework, which has been adopted by the BARMM Regional Peace and Order Council (RPOC).
OP1.2 : a) 0, b) 0, c) 1, d) 0 Philippines: Technical meetings were conducted between MILG and UNDP technical personnel in developing the Bangsamoro CORE framework, which has been adopted by the BARMM Regional Peace and Order Council (RPOC).
OP2.1 – 0 Indonesia : 14 May 2020, UNDP conducted consultation meetings with the Coordinating Ministry for Human Development and Cultural Affairs, The Coordinating Ministry for Political, Legal and Security Affairs, and the National Counter-Terrorism Agency (BNPT) to receive inputs and updates towards the design of the Project’s phase II. On 21 July 2020 UNDP Indonesia convened the first meeting with representatives from EU Delegation in Indonesia, UNDP BRH, and UNOCT. On 2 October 2020, UNDP convened its first Project Partner Meeting under the new Phase. Philippines: 22 October 2020, UNDP Philippines conducted a project coordination meeting on Phase II for the EU-Delegation in the Philippines, UNOCT and Bangkok Regional Hub. Indonesia: The Project is consulting with the Center for Peace and Conflict Resolutions Studies (PSDRK) of the University of Defense (UNHAN) to proceed with revitalizing the National Violence Monitoring System (NVMS).
OP2.2 - 0 Launched social media campaignCreators Against Covid or #SehatAnitHoax. The nine videos received a total of 2,356,797 views, 117,712 thumbs up and 8,949 comments (as of 24 Sep 2020). Of the total audience who engaged in the thumbs up/down feature on the videos, 98.9 percent gave positive responses.
Consultations held with SparkBlue, UNDP HQ and regional experts to determine most appropriate structure for CoP.
Philippines: 24-26 October 2020, the UNDP conducted a series of partners meetings to discuss potential areas for collaboration on PCVE. These included partners from the Provincial Government of Lanao del Sur, Bangsamoro Youth Commission, Al-Qalam Institute of Ateneo de Manila University, and the Ministry of the Interior and Local Government.
OP3.1 – TBD UNDP BRH held discussions with online gaming experts to determine whether a youth programme could be based around the link between gaming, hate speech and radicalization. UNDP will continue to explore partnership options with Google at the national level in the next reporting period. Indonesia: The Project partnered with SETARA Institute to implement the “Tolerant City” activity in five Cities to build common Early Warning and Early Response System (EWERS) with stakeholders at the community level. Philippines: In partnership with the Office of the Sangguniang Kabataan PanlalawigangPederasyon (Youth Council Provincial Federation) of the Province of Lanao del Sur, UNDP provided support for the conduct of the 2nd Datu a BantogensaRanaw, an advocacy-based, video production, and online inter-local government unit (LGU) competition Thailand: UNDP continued work with the production company to produce videos for an online campaign against hate speech, particularly around developing one additional video that address the rise of hate speech since the Pandemic.
OP3.2 – 0
OP3.3 – 0 UNDP Malaysia Resident Representative—Niloy Banerjee—and UNDP Malaysia Senior Governance Advisor—David Ennis—had a courtesy meeting with SEARCCT’s Director-General, His Excellency ChuahTeong Ban, on 26 June 2020. UNDP briefed SEARCCT on the current work with MOHA to develop the NAP PVE and invited SEARCCT to participate in the development process. On 5 OctoberUNDP met with the Ministry of National Unity’s Secretary-General to discuss potential areas of collaboration under output 3.
OP3.4 – TBC UNDP BRH established a strategy with the Oxford Internet Institute on monitoring data and insights relating to counter/alternative narratives content. Some of the key areas of engagement are as follows: - To provide in-depth analysis (beyond what social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter can typically provide) on the dissemination and impact of content produced by ExtremeLives; - Highlight the characteristics of different types of content that did particularly well or did not perform particularly well; - Outcomes to be summarized in a report on best practices and guidelines and a toolkit
OP3.5 – TBC Throughout Phase II of this Project, UNDP BRH plans to create an online regional platform to connect and support local level women peacebuilders and mediators across the region, providing opportunities for training, exchanges, and connections to policy processes. As a first step in this process, UNDP BRH held a call with the Project’s 4 country offices to explain the objectives and vision of the activity, ensure that it aligned with their national-level approach, and determine the level of involvement that each country office is interested in having. UNDP BRH and UNDP Philippines held a dialogue with the country offices under this Project to determine future strategy for regional women’s insider mediator platform.

PVE Project In Sri Lanka

PVE in Southeast Asia Phase II Output 1.Structural foundation in place in Indonesia and Philippines to develop Sub-National Action Plans Output 2: - 3 Knowledge Management Advisory Boards Established in Thailand, Philippines and Indonesia - 2.2: Signed LoA with universities in Thailand, Philippines and Indonesia to launch National PCVE Observatories - 9 online meetings and exchanges between practitioners organized through the Knowledge Management Platforms Output 3: - 14 religious-based organizations engaged on violent extremism - 25 representative of local government engaged in training of trainers on detecting early signs of radicalization - Grants issued to establish civic empowerment platform
PVE in Maldives Output 1: - Developed Hate Speech lexicon - Developed 1 annual report on social cohesion and violence Output 2: - Conducting a national dialogue on women, youth and religious leaders - Held policy dialogue with national government on NAPs for PCVE - Developed 1 internet literacy programme - Regional knowledge exchange on best practices and lessons learned on PVE framework - 1 community assessment conducted to identify areas of tension and gaps in local governance Output 3: 3 youth leadership programes conducted
PVE in Sri Lanka Output 1: - 2 Working groups set up to conduct data and trend analysis on early signs of radicalization - 3 knowledge product on conflict analysis - 8 sub-grant issued to support PCVE working group - 1 functional centre established to collect and consolidate data on hate speech, social cohesion and violence - 1 partnership gap analysis completed Output 2: - Multi-stakeholder dialogues completed on promoting social cohesion and preventing violence - 1 university programme developed on educating and training media personnel on ethical use of the internet. - 4 regional exchanges with CSOs on PCVE - 2 community risk assessment conducted to identify gaps in local governance Output 3 - 1 training conducted for religious leaders on youth inclusion and reconciliation - 4 youth leadership training conducted to increase youth capacity and participation in entrepreneurship, content creation and policymaking
Preventing of violent extremism with particular attention to youth in Bangladesh, Indonesia, Maldives and Sri Lanka

PVE Project in Southeast Asia Phase I
Indicator 1.2 -- 4 Indicator 1.3 -- 4 Indicator 2.1 -- 1 Indicator 2.2 -- 1 Indicator 2.3 -- 1 Indicator 3.1 -- 1 Indicator 3.2 -- 10 Indicator 3.3 -- 20 Indicator 3.4 -- 50% Indicator 3.5 -- 50%

 Indicator 1.1 – 2 o 1: The 5 academic researchers who have contributed to the joint UN Women-UNDP publications on masculinity, femininity and violent extremism have worked together and collaborated to provide concrete recommendations on addressing gender and VE in programming, research, and policy development o 1: UNDP supported in organizing and inviting relevant researchers and experts to participate in the 6th Annual Global Hedayah Conference on P/CVE, which brought together experts from around the region to discuss best practices and emerging trends in violent extremism and approaches to PVE.  Indicator 1.2 -- 5 o In partnership with UN Women, UNDP commissioned 5 research papers to be produced on the theme of “the nexus between masculinities, femininities, and violent extremism in Asia”. In 2019 the papers were produced, edited and finalized by country offices. The papers will be compiled into a single publication which will be published in early 2020.  Indicator 1.3 -- 5 o 1: Meeting on 23 January 2019 on Research Platform on Peacebuilding and PVE to Inform PVE Policy and Programming. The meeting was attended by researchers from various institutions. From the meeting, research teams were formed, and priority research topics were identified. o 1: On 29 April, UNDPs PVE team held a regional meeting with representatives from the European Union delegation and relevant UNDP Country Offices. The retreat focused on country and regional level updates on the initiatives and activities undertaken by both the Regional Hub and the Country Offices, sharing good practices on reporting and communications and on developing National Actions Plans. The meeting also provided an opportunity to discuss future activities relating to PVE in South East Asia. o 2: UNDP Indonesia held 2 dialogues with national stakeholders to share perspectives and develop frameworks for protecting the rights of victims of violent extremism o 1: UNDP Thailand held a consultation with national and regional level stakeholders to share lessons learned and best practices on developing national guidelines and frameworks on preventing violent extremism.  Indicator 2.1 -- 2 o UNDP Indonesia developed a NAP-PCVE that contains a holistic methodology. UNDP Indonesia continues to work with relevant government counterparts to develop a holistic implementation plan and budget to ensure inclusive and effective implementation of the NAP o The Philippines NAP-PCVE was approved in May 2019 and contains a holistic methodology which is grounded in gender equality and human rights norms.  Indicator 2.2 -- 2 o 1: The Philippines NAP-PCVE was approved in May 2019 and contains specific commitments to CSOs and gender equality in its methodology. UNDP also ensured that UN Women was engaged in the designing of the NAP methodology to enhance gender analysis. UNDP Philippines worked closely with UN Women Philippines to provide inputs on the development of a guidance note on the implementation of gender provisions in the Philippines NAP on PCVE . o 1: UNDP Indonesia is working with government and relevant stakeholders to develop a Matrix on the NAP on PVE which is still being discussed and debated by government counterparts, but includes many gender equality related topics . UNDP Indonesia will continue to facilitate the NAP harmonization and matrix process in the next quarter to ensure that relevant government ministries are responsible for commitments and allocating budget towards these topics.  Indicator 2.3 -- 100% o UNDP Indonesia is continuing to work closely with government and relevant stakeholders to develop a Matrix on the NAP on PVE which is still being discussed and debated by government counterparts, as well as to facilitate the NAP harmonization process. o UNDP Philippines continues to support the implementation of PCVE interventions for communities affected by conflict, PDL-TRCs and VEOs, religious leaders, and learning institutions. Pending the issuance of the signed Executive Order and rules and regulations for the implementation of the NAP-PCVE, UNDP is working on implementing various interventions in line with the recommendations put forth in the NAP  Indicator 3.1 -- 0 o Target was achieved in 2018. 2019 saw the continued expansion, maintenance and improvement of the YouTube and Facebook #ExtremeLives online regional platforms.  Indicator 3.2 -- 38 o 38 clips, trailers, and full-length episode ExtremeLives videos were produced in 2019. See ExtremeLives YoutTube page for evidence.  Indicator 3.3 -- 38 o 16 creators were trained in the 2019 Indonesia Creators for Change Bootcamp (29 October 2019), and 22 creators were trained in the Philippines Creators for Change Bootcamp (14 November 2019).  Indicator 3.4 -- 100% o In partnership with UNDP Philippines, UNDP Philippines facilitated a design workshop bringing together women’s insider mediators from around the region on issues relating to violent extremism. A follow up activity is expected to include sharing best practices on countering harmful gendered extremist narratives, in the next project phase.  Indicator 3.5 -- 100% o UNDP Indonesia trained and provided funding for a select group of youth across the country to develop and produce both offline and online programs intended to build tolerance and respect for diversity amongst youth in Indonesia. UNDP Thailand produced the Youth Co-Lab 2019 event which provided youth entrepreneurs the opportunity to pitch and develop their social innovation ideas to further respect for diversity and tolerance in Thailand. Their projects are being financially supported by UNDP Thailand.
